The lex Furia testamentaria, ae. 183, imposed a penalty ol lour times the excess upon any one (except the cognates of the person by whom the testator had been manumitted or emancipated, Ulpian, reg. 28. 7), who took as a legacy, or mortis causa, rnore thau 1000 asses from the same person: itis remarkable lor being the first enactment os the civil law relating to inheritance in which cognatio is recognised as a title. As Gaius remarks, it altogether failed in its object, ‘qui enim verbi gratia quinque millium aeris patrimonium habebat, poterat quinque hominibus singulis millenos asses legando toturn patrimonium erogare’ ii. 225. The lex Voconia, tac. 169 (Cic. pro Balbo 8, in Verr. 2. 1. 42, 43, de senect. 5, de fin. 2. 17, de repub. 3. 10), which Gaius regards as an attempt to provide a more effectual remedy against intestacy, seems really to bave been only a relaxation oi the lex Furia ih favour os wealthy testators; any person ranked in the first class oi the census as owner oi roo,ooo sesterces or upwards (Cic. in Verr. loc cit.) might bequeath away as much as he pleased, provided no legacy or gilt mortis causa exceeded in amount the share which the heir (or each of two or more co-heirs) received himself. Both statutes were superseded by the lex Falcidia, tac. 40, tbe terms os which ran as follows, ‘quicunque civis Romanus posthanc legem rogatam testamentum saciet, is quantum cuique civi Romano pecuniam iure publico dare legare volet, ius po- testasque esto, dum ita detur legatum, ne minus quam partem quartam hereditatis eo testamento heredes capiant' Dig. 35. κ. 1. pr.
